data.title: Google honours Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan in its Doodle: All about the king of Qawwali
meta_keywords: facts on ustad nusrat fateh ali khan
facts on nusrat fateh ali khan
nusrat fateh ali khan's birth anniversary
data.meta_description: On the 67th birth anniversary of the king of Qawwali, Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, here are some facts you should not miss about him.
data.text:
Search engine Google occasionally honours events and anniversaries of well-known personalities by making some spontaneous changes in its logo on its homepage. Today, Google celebrates 67th birth anniversary of the legend of the Qawwali genre, Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan. According to the search engine "Khan brought Qawwali from modest origins to international attention. He collaborated with, and influenced, countless musicians. Some performances could even last as long as ten hours."

advertisement

The doodle features Khan singing with other qawwals. To honour the legend, let's read some facts we have collected on what would have been his 67th birthday.

Facts you should not miss about the legend, Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan:

Born as Parvez Fateh Ali Khan, Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan is also known as NFAK, Khan Sahib, Shahenshah-e-Qawwali

Khan's father wanted him to pursue a career in medicine because he felt that Qawwali singers did not have much status in society but relented to his interest in Qawwali

Khan's first public performance as the leader of the Qawwali party was at a studio recording. The performance was broadcast as part of an annual music festival organised by Radio Pakistan, known as Jashn-e-Baharan

Khan sang mainly in Urdu and Punjabi and occasionally in Persian, Braj Bhasha and Hindi

His first major hit in Pakistan was the song Haq Ali Ali

Nusrat Khan became so famous in the world that he started getting invitations to perform overseas. Khan performed in London, Paris in 1985 and 1988, New York, Japan in 1987. He also performed at the 5th Asian Traditional Performing Art Festival in Japan

Khan also teamed with Peter Gabriel on the soundtrack to 'The Last Temptation of Christ', with Canadian musician Michael Brook on the albums Mustt Mustt and Night Song (1996)

Teaming up with international stars gave Khan the opportunity to stylise his songs by blending Qawwalis with the Western music

Before his death, he had recorded a song each for two Hindi films, Aur Pyaar Ho Gaya and Kachche Dhaage

He sang 'Saya bhi saath jab chhod jaye' for the movie Dillagi which was released two years after Khan's death

Khan contributed the song 'Gurus of Peace' to the album Vande Mataram, composed by A. R. Rahman, which was released on the 50th anniversary of India's independence

Ustad Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan died of a sudden cardiac arrest on August 16, 1997

In 1987, Khan received the President of Pakistan's Award for Pride of Performance for his contribution to Pakistani music

In 1995, he received the UNESCO Music Prize, Grand Prix des Ameriques in 1996, Arts and Culture Prize, the 'Legends' award in 2005

Time magazine's listed him as one of the top 12 artists and thinkers in the last 60 years

In 2010, he was included in CNN's list of the twenty most iconic musicians.

Let's just listen.

AtMigration

Published On:
